conclusion: To determine whether the pedestrian can catch up with the bus, we need to analyze the motion of both the pedestrian and the bus using the provided velocity-time (v-t) graphs.
The pedestrian runs at a constant speed. The bus starts from rest and accelerates uniformly.
From the graph, the bus reaches a velocity of 8 m/s at 8 seconds.

premise: The bus reaches a velocity of 8 m/s at 8 seconds.
conclusion: The acceleration of the bus is 1 m/s².

premise: The bus starts from rest and accelerates uniformly with an acceleration of 1 m/s².
conclusion: The position of the bus at t = 8 seconds is 32 meters.
From the graph, the pedestrian's speed is 8 m/s.

premise: The pedestrian runs at a constant speed of 8 m/s.
conclusion: The distance covered by the pedestrian in 8 seconds is 64 meters.
The pedestrian starts 36 meters away from the bus.

premise: The bus has traveled 32 meters and the pedestrian has traveled 64 meters at t = 8 seconds.
conclusion: The relative position of the pedestrian with respect to the bus is 32 meters.

premise: The pedestrian started 36 meters behind the bus and is now 32 meters ahead.
conclusion: The pedestrian is 4 meters behind the bus at t = 8 seconds.

premise: After t = 8 seconds, the bus continues to accelerate while the pedestrian maintains a constant speed.
conclusion: The pedestrian cannot catch up to the bus after the initial 8 seconds.
